intro: Linanthus serrulatus, commonly known as the narrow-leaf flax, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae and is characterized by its slender, upright stems and small, blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid environments. Its leaves are narrow and serrated, giving it its scientific name. Linanthus serrulatus is often found in open grasslands and along streambanks, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing nectar for pollinators.
